facts.text: Respondent was a Zamindar of Gadhi, Baghu and Santokpore Villages in Uttar Pradesh and claimed the plaint-schedule lands were his Sir.
Appellants claimed they were admitted by the respondent as hereditary tenants after paying Rs. 40,000 towards premium and were in possession of the said lands.

Dispute likely to cause breach of peace; Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Baghpat, took proceedings under s. 145 CrPC, attached disputed lands on October 8, 1948, and placed them in possession of a supurdgiar.
Magistrate, by order dated March 20, 1950, found appellants in possession and declared them entitled to possession until evicted in due course of law.

On June 30, 1950, respondent filed six suits in Revenue Court (Additional Collector, Meerut) under s. 180 U.P. Tenancy Act against appellants for eviction and damages, alleging lands were Sir and appellants trespassed based on wrong criminal court order.
Suits consolidated but stayed on August 14, 1951, under r. 4 of Rules under U.P. Ordinance No. III of 1951.
On September 22, 1952, on respondent's application, Revenue Court ordered restarting trial under r. 5.
Suits transferred to Civil Court (first Additional Munsif, Ghaziabad), who held triable only by Revenue Court and retransferred.
Additional Collector held lands were Sir and khud kasht of respondent; appellants not admitted as hereditary tenants.
Appellants appealed to Commissioner, Meerut; Additional Commissioner held one appeal (legal reps of Jahana) abated due to improper presentation, res judicata in others; agreed lands Sir, no tenancy.
Second appeals to Board of Revenue, Allahabad; accepted findings, negated non-maintainability plea; dismissed appeals.
Appellants filed present appeals by special leave against Board of Revenue order.
U.P. Government Notification dated August 9, 1951, under Ordinance No. III of 1951; rules amended October 8, 1952.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal by legal representatives of Jahana was properly presented to the Commissioner.
Whether decision in abated appeal operates as res judicata in connected appeals.
Whether Revenue Court had jurisdiction to try the suits under s. 180 U.P. Tenancy Act.
Whether suits abated under r. 5 of U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Rules.
Whether finding that appellants were not hereditary tenants vitiated by errors of law.
Whether damages award contrary to law as no evidence or argument thereon.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appeal by legal reps of Jahana properly presented to Commissioner.
Even if abated, no res judicata in connected appeals.
Revenue Court had no jurisdiction to try suits.
Suits abated under r. 5 of Rules as stayed under r. 4.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Rules r.4, r.5

petitioner_arguments.text: Finding on no hereditary tenancy vitiated: (i) no presumption under s.79 Evidence Act for khatauni 1355 fasli; (ii) burden on respondent due to s.145 CrPC order; (iii) material evidence ignored; (iv) different proof standards; (v) ignored rights under ss.10,16,20 U.P. Tenancy Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Evidence Act ss.4,79; CrPC s.145; U.P. Tenancy Act ss.10,16,20

petitioner_arguments.text: Damages award illegal: no witness evidence, no argument.
Possession taken/retained in accordance with law via s.145 CrPC order; plaints admit possession post-order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: CrPC s.145; U.P. Tenancy Act s.180

respondent_arguments.text: Lands were Sir; appellants trespassers, not admitted as tenants.
Applied for restarting suits under r.5.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Rules r.5

court_reasoning.text: First two contentions (appeal presentation, res judicata) need not be decided as others rejected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rejecting other points makes these immaterial.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent finding of three courts that appellants not hereditary tenants is factual, not vitiated by law: no presumption under s.79 Evidence Act as khatauni not substantially compliant; burden immaterial as full evidence considered; no ignored evidence or different standards; ss.10,16,20 inapplicable sans tenancy.
Damages plea not raised below, not open now.

Revenue Court has jurisdiction under s.180 U.P. Tenancy Act for ejectment of person occupying without consent or lawful authority; appellants neither had consent nor possession per law (s.145 CrPC only declares past possession, no title/right; police order only).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Possession under s.145 not 'in accordance with law' meaning with title.

court_reasoning.text: Suits not abated under amended r.5: restarted under old rules, no subsisting stay; exception for Sir lands where no rights accrued to defendants under s.16 etc.; contention rejected by Board finally.

holdings.text: Appellants not hereditary tenants; lands Sir of respondent.
Revenue Court has jurisdiction under s.180 to eject trespassers without title; s.145 CrPC order does not confer title or lawful possession.
Suits did not abate under Rules.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dinomoni Chowdhrani v. Brojo Mohini Chowdhrani
precedents_cited.relevance: Orders under s.145 CrPC are police orders preventing breach of peace, decide no title.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Tenancy Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction for ejectment of unauthorized occupier; suits triable by Revenue Courts; no ejectment if consent or lawful possession.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Magistrate declares possession on preliminary order date only; no power to give possession or title.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Rebuttable presumption for certified copies only if substantially compliant.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Rules, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Stay and abatement of suits; exceptions for Sir lands sans accrued rights.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Land Records Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for issuing certified copies of records.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, affirming the Board of Revenue's dismissal; held appellants not tenants, Revenue Court had jurisdiction, no abatement, s.145 order ineffective against s.180 suit.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellants; eviction and damages upheld.

key_quotes.text: "These orders are merely police orders made to prevent breaches of the peace. They decide no question of title."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains effect of s.145 CrPC order (citing Privy Council).

key_quotes.text: "A provisional order of a Magistrate in regard to possession irrespective of the rights of the parties cannot enable a person to resist the suit under s. 180 of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interplay of CrPC s.145 and Tenancy Act s.180.

key_quotes.text: "The words 'possession in accordance with the law for the time being in force' in the context can only mean possession with title."
key_quotes.speaker: court
